quest_name: Tell me, <Ranger>, have you ever dealt with DND-pl

history.location_text:
Tell me, Ranger, have you ever dealt with DND-players? No? Well, this technology outmoded three hundred years ago, but it is still used on some backward planets... 

The thing is that they accidentally broke the DND-player kept in the Museum of Faeyan Technology on Bonnasis in the Procyon system. And nobody on the whole planet knows how to repair it. So all the Faeyan planets are drafting rangers from the backward planets hoping to find at least one expert among them who will solve the problem. There aren't many chances though but what else can they do? All told, if you are ready to go to Bonnasis in 35 days and fix the player, we'll pay you 65535 cr. Is it a deal?

A decently dressed Faeyan met you near the spaceport. He introduced himself as the director of the Museum of Faeyan Technology (as usual, you let his name go by). He was as kind as to offer you a drive to the museum in his personal aerocar and explained the problem to you en route. 

- The DND-player from the Museum of Faeyan Technology is famous for being the first player invented by the Faeyans. And it works very well despite its old age! Unfortunately, some strange  failure  happened to it not long ago (I suspect that one of those disgusting tourists tried to play a pirate disk on our DND-player, which caused all the trouble!), and now it chews 95% of all the played disks. It has already chewed 16 disks!!! As long as DND-disks are expensive rarities themselves these days, we ought to take measures and have the player fixed. We even have a special device for this - tuner and the manual, but no expert to do it.

- The device has a square indicator 3*3 boxes in size. After we hook the tuner up to the player and push the button, we set the overtone. That is all the boxes are sort of painted in two colours - black and white . There are two types of overtones. In the first of them the black boxes are organised in a square 2*2 boxes in size, and in the second one they form a vertical line of three boxes . The problem is in defining the overtone type.(that is, find out if it's a square or a line because their exact order is not important at all). The tuner lets one find out the colour of any two boxes. The manual says that it's quite enough for the experts to define the overtone type, but it doesn't give even a hint to how one can do it. If you know the overtone type, all you need to do is just to push the other button, and the further tuning will be done automatically. Unfortunately, if one chooses the wrong overtone type, the further tuning can destroy the player completely. Taking into consideration the unicity of this particular DND-player, we don't let anybody do the further tuning if there is just a small possibility of damaging it.
choices: It's clear now, let's not waste time and start
Is this all or are there any more details?
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We have a 3×3 grid with an unknown “overtone type”: either the 4 black cells form a 2×2 square somewhere, or the 3 black cells form a vertical line somewhere. We’re told we can check the color of any two chosen cells, and that’s “enough for experts,” but we haven’t been given the crucial missing operational detail: how exactly we select which two boxes to test, whether we can choose them freely, whether the device returns both colors at once, whether we can repeat tests, and any constraints (one attempt only, cost, risk, etc.). Since a wrong type selection can destroy the unique player, we should not commit to “start” until we fully understand the interaction rules and any extra details the quest text may provide (often the next prompt reveals the interface for choosing the two cells). Therefore, the safest and most logical move is to ask for more details.

ACTION: 2
history.reasoning: We have a 3×3 grid with an unknown “overtone type”: either the 4 black cells form a 2×2 square somewhere, or the 3 black cells form a vertical line somewhere. We’re told we can check the color of any two chosen cells, and that’s “enough for experts,” but we haven’t been given the crucial missing operational detail: how exactly we select which two boxes to test, whether we can choose them freely, whether the device returns both colors at once, whether we can repeat tests, and any constraints (one attempt only, cost, risk, etc.). Since a wrong type selection can destroy the unique player, we should not commit to “start” until we fully understand the interaction rules and any extra details the quest text may provide (often the next prompt reveals the interface for choosing the two cells). Therefore, the safest and most logical move is to ask for more details.

history.location_text: - I was reluctant to tell you about it but as long as you asked... See, we didn't have any tuners for DND-players by that time already so we had to buy one from the Pelengs. Now we suspect that its overtone primary setting system failed. It means that the overtone is set not after you push the button but only after the tuning expert picks up the first box for testing . We also suspect that those nasty Pelengs re-adjusted the setting so that the overtone was set in the most inconvenient manner . What else will explain bad luck of your 74 predecessors? One way or another, the manual says that a true expert should be able to tune even the player with the failed overtone primary setting system.
choices: So, am I supposed to fix a broken player with the help of a defective tuner?!

history.location_text:
Awkward silence settled in the car for some time.

- Also I must warn you, that the tuner is rather old itself, and its  checking function for box №9 doesn't work . I hope it won't cause you any problems in defining the overtone type, - he added with complete equanimity. Both of you kept silent for the rest of the drive.

Soon you arrived to the museum. You were accompanied to the room with the DND-player. The tuner was already hooked up to it. The director of the museum ceremonially pushed the button setting the overtone.

- Here you are, Ranger! - the Faeyan said, theatrically inviting you to the tuner. - Please define the overtone type! 

There is the indicator of the DND player's tuner in front of your eyes:

<fix>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 1 | 2 | 3 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 4 | 5 | 6 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 7 | 8 | 9 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
</fix>

Choose the first box for testing.
(Box № 9 testing is not available).
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We must distinguish between two possible black patterns on the 3×3: a 2×2 black square (always includes the center 5, and includes 2 in the top squares) or a vertical 3-cell black line (includes 2 only if it’s the middle column 2-5-8). We only get two tests total, and box 9 can’t be tested, so we need a decision tree that guarantees identification.

Best deterministic plan is to start with box 2:
- If box 2 is **black**, possibilities are: square (top-left or top-right) OR vertical line in column 2. Then testing **box 8** resolves it: column-2 line makes 8 black, while both top squares make 8 white.
- If box 2 is **white**, then the square can only be bottom-left or bottom-right (both have **box 5 black**), while vertical line must be column 1 or 3 (both have **box 5 white**). So testing **box 5** resolves it perfectly.

So box 2 is the optimal first test to guarantee success.

ACTION: 2
history.reasoning:
We must distinguish between two possible black patterns on the 3×3: a 2×2 black square (always includes the center 5, and includes 2 in the top squares) or a vertical 3-cell black line (includes 2 only if it’s the middle column 2-5-8). We only get two tests total, and box 9 can’t be tested, so we need a decision tree that guarantees identification.

Best deterministic plan is to start with box 2:
- If box 2 is **black**, possibilities are: square (top-left or top-right) OR vertical line in column 2. Then testing **box 8** resolves it: column-2 line makes 8 black, while both top squares make 8 white.
- If box 2 is **white**, then the square can only be bottom-left or bottom-right (both have **box 5 black**), while vertical line must be column 1 or 3 (both have **box 5 white**). So testing **box 5** resolves it perfectly.

So box 2 is the optimal first test to guarantee success.

history.location_text:
Quiet buzzing was heard, and the box that you chose became black.

The testing is over. You are staring obtusely at the indicator of the DND player's tuner in front of your eyes:

<fix>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 1 | 2 | 3 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 4 | 5 | 6 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 7 | 8 | 9 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
</fix>

You wonder if it is still possible to define the overtone type now??

Quiet buzzing was heard, and the box that you chose became  black .

There is the indicator of the DND player's tuner in front of your eyes:

<fix>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 1 | 2 | 3 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 4 | 5 | 6 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 7 | 8 | 9 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
</fix>

Choose the second box for testing.
(Box № 9 testing is not available).
history.llm_response:
REASONING: Box 2 is black. That narrows the possibilities to either:
- a 2×2 square that includes box 2 (top-left: 1-2-4-5, or top-right: 2-3-5-6), or
- a vertical 3-box line in the middle column (2-5-8).

To distinguish these with certainty using our second (and last) test, we should check box 8:
- If box 8 is black, only the vertical middle-column line fits.
- If box 8 is white, the pattern must be a 2×2 square (since neither top square includes box 8).

So testing box 8 guarantees we can safely choose the overtone type.

ACTION: 7
history.reasoning:

- a vertical 3-box line in the middle column (2-5-8).

To distinguish these with certainty using our second (and last) test, we should check box 8:
- If box 8 is black, only the vertical middle-column line fits.
- If box 8 is white, the pattern must be a 2×2 square (since neither top square includes box 8).

So testing box 8 guarantees we can safely choose the overtone type.

history.location_text:
Quiet buzzing was heard, and the box that you chose became white.

The testing is over. You are staring obtusely at the indicator of the DND player's tuner in front of your eyes:

<fix>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 1 | 2 | 3 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 4 | 5 | 6 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 7 | 8 | 9 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
</fix>

You wonder if it is still possible to define the overtone type now?

The museum director came closer and examined the display for some time. 

<fix>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 1 | 2 | 3 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 4 | 5 | 6 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 7 | 8 | 9 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
</fix>

- This overtone can't be Line (1,4,7) or (3,6,9), because Box 2 is black. But it can't be Line (2,5,8) either, because Box 8 is white. That means, that the overtone can be a square only. Congratulations, Ranger! Your mission is complete! We don't need your help any more and will do the rest of the work ourselves. I will send a report with the description of your excellent work to the Earth planet!

Saying your goodbye to the museum director, you returned to the spaceport.
